questions.question: Which of the following is not a downside of fully meshing BGP peers?

options.text: IBGP peers must use OSPF as an IGP.
IBGP peers must be peered with EBGP peers.
IBGP peers must be limited in numbers.
IBGP peers must be fully meshed with each other.

questions.question: What kind of routing protocol runs within an organization's or enterprise's autonomous system?

Approximately how many routing table entries does an Internet BGP router currently hold?

options.text: BGP permits highly flexible routing policy.
BGP advertises any intra-AS topology changes.
BGP is a selective routing protocol.

questions.question: What's another name for a 'path attribute'?

options.text: Send a Notification message to ask if the peer is 'alive'.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?

options.text: BGP is the only routing protocol used to connect autonomous systems.
BGP is a very popular inter-AS routing protocol, but OSPF can also be used.
There are several routing protocols used to connect autonomous systems, but BGP has become popular recently.
BGP is a very popular inter-AS routing protocol, but IS-IS can also be used.

questions.question: Why do you need to be careful using BGP 'redistribute' statements?

options.text: Because they can create network loops.
Because they will not share private addresses/prefixes.
Because they will share the entire set of local IGP prefixes if you don't use some form of filtering.
Because they will only redistribute a maximum of 1024 prefixes from each autonomous system.

options.text: The state model is called a Finite State Machine.
Each state has a direct path to the 'Idle' state.
There are time duration dependencies for all state transitions.
The state machine has six states.

questions.question: Which two statements are used to instruct a router to share prefixes?

options.text: To differentiate between IBGP and EBGP-connected peers.
To enable a BGP router to select the best path to a network prefix.
To communicate how many BGP peers each BGP router has.

questions.question: How do BGP peers exchange path attribute information?

options.text: Paths marked with an 'i' at the end of their AS path description.

questions.question: In Accumulated IGP ('AIGP'), what is being accumulated?

options.text: All routes with an AS Hop count of more than one.
All routes received from another BGP peer.
All routes received through an Update message.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the tiebreaking process is correct?

options.text: There are 10 types of path attribute to compare.
Some path attributes are optional, so they can be omitted from the best path selection process.
The list of path attributes must be compared in strict order.

questions.question: Which of the following does not exist in a modern network that uses switches rather than hubs.

options.text: all interfaces in the same VLAN

Bridges and switches increase the number of collision domains in a network.

options.text: (i) based on QoS, (ii) based on MAC addresses

options.text: After the Source Address field and before the Type field.

options.text: It loops frames to add redundancy to the network.
It is used to separate VLANs.

options.text: In the Type field, just after the Source Address field.

options.text: To transfer information from one location to another

options.text: The queue depth reaches the minimum occupancy threshold.
The queue depth reaches a point where drop probability is 100.
The queue depth reaches a point where drop probability is 1.
The queue depth reaches the maximum occupancy threshold.

options.text: The greater the chance of the packet being discarded when compared with packets marked with a lower class
The lower the chance of the packet being discarded when compared to other packets in the same class
The lower the chance of the packet being discarded when compared with packets marked with a lower class
The greater the chance of the packet being discarded when compared to other packets in the same class

questions.question: How many QoS classes are supported by the Ethernet standard?

options.text: Nodes not in any DS domain.

options.text: A queue is infinite in length.

It will only work properly if the flow of traffic is bursty.
Packets arriving are put in different queues in a round-robin fashion, depending on which arrive first.

options.text: To provide resiliency and additional capacity.

options.text: IP can only be used for Enterprise networks.

options.text: It is possible only if 128-bit IPv4 addressing is used.
It is not possible - you must use one or the other, but not both.
It is possible for both to co-exist.

options.text: Because TCP is the fastest choice.

options.text: They are used by Applications to specify the use of TCP or UDP.

They are used by the Network layer to determine whether to drop packets.

options.text: Use the BGP transport protocol instead of TCP.

options.text: Private IP addresses use 24-bit length addresses.

options.text: 16 bits, network part then host part

options.text: An up/down status identifier for the link to the next hop.

questions.question: When a router makes a routing decision and sends a packet to the next hop, what happens at the next hop router?

options.text: The next hop router uses the routing decision already made by the previous router and sends the packet to the predetermined next hop.
The next hop router makes its own routing decision and sends the packet onto the new next hop.
The next hop router extracts the payload from the incoming packet and creates a new IP packet with its own source address, before route selection and transmission to the new next hop.
The next hop router sends the packet to the destination address without performing a route lookup.

questions.question: In an IP network, is the path from A to B always the same as from B to A but in reverse?

options.text: Only if the path is an even number of hops.

options.text: How much capacity is available in a network for transmitting data.

The path data follows when transmitted from source to destination.

questions.question: Which of these factors is not a primary routing protocol characteristic?

options.text: How the routing protocol scales with network size.
How quality of service (QoS) can be delivered.

questions.question: Knowledge Assessment  IP v4 Topology Considerations Why is quick convergence a positive characteristic for a routing protocol?

options.text: Because slow convergence creates much larger routing tables.
Because quick convergence reduces the likelihood of node and link failures.
Because during the time a network is not converged, the routing process may have unpredictable results.
Because quick convergence increases router packet throughput during converged conditions too.

questions.question: What is a common reason for loops forming in IP networks?

options.text: Routing table updates being affected by bit errors in transmission between nodes.
Routing tables not reflecting the true state of the network topology.

options.text: Large routing tables are expensive in terms of memory requirements.

Large routing tables require more host IP addresses for each router.
Large routing tables create larger routing updates.

questions.question: What is a primary use for Border Routers?

options.text: To act as an aggregation/concentration point for a large number of links from other networks.
To filter and limit traffic based upon application type.
To manage routing updates traveling between autonomous systems.
To provide packet replication for multicast services.

questions.question: What is a possible consequence when a loop forms?

options.text: The router will close down all ports.
Packets will be delivered to random destinations.

questions.question: How does BGP solve the problem of exponential routing table growth?

options.text: By restricting routing updates to certain parts of the day.
By using dedicated massive memory arrays for routing tables.
By restricting routing updates to only pre-determined routers.
Through route summarization between autonomous systems.

options.text: LDP and the IGP through a negotiation

questions.question: Which is the main difference between LDP and RSVP-TE?

options.text: RSVP-TE provides greater control over LSPs
LDP provides greater control over LSPs
LDP has a higher operational overhead

questions.question: Based on what does RSVP-TE select a Label Switched Path (LSP)?

options.text: A manually defined Forwarding Equivalence Class (FEC)
The RFC with the highest number

questions.question: For every network prefix in the FIB, LDP in the Label Edge Routers (LERs) and Label Switch Routers (LSRs) binds FECs to...?
Which area plays the main role in the OSPF concept?
The routing table is required by router in order to forward traffic.
What type of protocol is OSPF?
All areas must be connected to the Backbone area.
What are the reasons to divide one large network into multiple smaller areas? (Choose 2)

options.text: It increases the number of routing recalculations in the routing database.
It reduces the number of routing recalculations in the routing database.
It increases the total number of possible connected subscribers.
It makes all changes inside any area invisible for all other areas.
It simplifies the architecture of the network.

questions.question: Choose the true statement.

options.text: OSPF is used to exchange routing information and calculate best paths to all sources.
OSPF is used to exchange routing information and calculate best paths to all destinations.
OSPF is used to forward data between sources and destinations.

questions.question: In the OSPF there are different roles routers can perform.
Area Border Router is the router which:

options.text: Connects one or more areas to the Backbone Area.
Represents the multi-access network and its attached routers to the rest of the OSPF area.
Whose interfaces belong to the same area.

questions.question: Which area plays the main role in the OSPF concept?
In a broadcast network, OSPF routers form adjacencies with which of the following?
Choose the Link-State Advertisements from the list (Choose three).
BDR stands for:
Each Autonomous Boundary Router (ABR) must have at least one interface connected to the Backbone Area.
Choose the Backbone Area.
In the OSPF there are different types of routers.
OSPF uses TCP as a transport protocol.
Which is a security principle from the CIA Triad?
Working with the CIA Triad usually requires...

options.text: .. prioritizing the Triad principles in their order (C-I-A).
. making sure to meet all Triad principles fully.
. choosing one of the principles according to business objectives.

questions.question: Which is the concept of controlling what a user can do after they are allowed access to a system?
Which risk treatment involves buying insurance or outsourcing the risk to another organization?
What is a weakness that could be exploited by a threat called?
Safeguards are also known as....?
What is the concept that a user cannot deny that they performed an action on a system called?
Standards relating to the specification of the IPsec protocol are published by whom?
Which of the following are both true statements about Transport mode compared with Tunnel mode?

options.text: Transport mode produces smaller packets, Tunnel mode is more secure
Transport mode produces smaller packets, Tunnel mode is less secure
Transport mode produces larger packets, Tunnel mode is less secure
Transport mode produces larger packets, Tunnel mode is more secure

questions.question: Pre-Shared Key (PSK) takes the form of ___

options.text: An electronic chip device containing a secure ID
A certificate generated by the device vendor
A pseudo-random numeric sequence generated as a software toke
A text string, entered manually by an administrator

questions.question: Which one of the following statements about Child SAs is true?

options.text: Child SAs are established before the IKE SA
Child SAs are related to one or more IKE SAs
Child SAs are renewed typically every 24 hours
Child SAs are created in unidirectional pairs

questions.question: IPsec sits at which layer of the OSI stack?
Which statement is correct about an IPsec VPN?

options.text: An IPsec VPN exists between two IPsec peers
An IPsec VPN is always secured by Pre-Shared Keys
An IPsec VPN only exists when IPsec is used in transport mode
An IPsec VPN consists of one Child SA pair

questions.question: ESP provides encryption and authentication, AH provides what?
Secure keys are used for what?

options.text: Traffic protection and outer header calculation
